Description: examines how Members are onboarded, equipped, and supported throughout their service—from new Member orientation through the tools and information systems that shape daily decision-making.

addresses the staffing crisis head-on: compensation, retention, career paths, professional development, and the knowledge management systems needed to preserve institutional memory across inevitable turnover.
reimagines the full stack of interactions between Congress and the public—from casework to policy input to civic education—for a digital age.
tackles the procurement, development, and security challenges that have left Congress technologically behind, with specific attention to responsible AI adoption.
envisions how CRS, CBO, GAO, and other congressional support offices can be integrated, modernized, and empowered to meet 21st-century demands.
proposes a new model for congressional oversight—one that emphasizes post-legislative scrutiny, real-time monitoring, and data-driven accountability over episodic hearings.
confronts the dysfunction of the current budget process and offers reforms calibrated to an era that demands both fiscal discipline and rapid response capability.
examines the committee system, floor procedures, and parliamentary practices that structure how Congress does its work—and how they might evolve.
focuses on law drafting, codification, and the legislative record—the documentary output that is Congress's lasting contribution to American governance.
addresses Congress's relationships with the executive and judicial branches, including the feedback loops needed to ensure laws work as intended.
draws lessons from peer parliaments around the world that have pioneered innovations Congress can adapt.
considers Congress's relationship with the broader ecosystem of organizations, experts, and citizens that support democratic governance.
Vol II of Rep bodies launch
